case_name: Civil Appeal Nos. 141 of 1971 and 268 of 1972

facts.text: Civil Appeal Nos. 141 of 1971 and 268 of 1972 arose from Gujarat High Court in S.C.A. Nos. 1 of 1968 and 1273 of 1967 respectively

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal Nos. 141 of 1971 and 268 of 1972. of the Gujarat High Court in S.C.A. Nos. 1 of 1968 and 1273 of 1967 respectively .

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2467 and 2468 of 1972 from judgments and orders dated 20th January 1972 of Delhi High Court in L.P.As Nos. 65-66 and 74 of 1970

anchor.surface_text: AND Civil Appeals Nos. 2467 2468 of 1972.  Appeals from the Judgments Orders dated the 20th January, 1972 of the Delhi High Court in L.P.As Nos. 65-66, and 74 of 1970 respectively .

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 12 of 1971, 17 and 471-474 of 1972 under Article 32 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: WITH Writ Petitions Nos. 12 of 1971, 17 471-474 of 1972 Petitions Under Article 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: The only question is whether Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Regulations could be amended by the Former Secretary of State Service Officers Conditions of Service Act, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The judgement by the Court was delivered by RAY, C.J.The only question which falls for determination in these petitions and appeal is whether Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Regulations companyld be amended by the Former Secretary of State,

facts.text: 1972 Act provides for variation or revocation of conditions of service of former Secretary of State Service Officers

anchor.surface_text: Service Officers  Conditions of Service  Act, 1972. The 1972 Act is to provide for the variation or revocation of the companyditions of service of former Secretary of State Service Officers in respect of certain matters

facts.text: Regulation 561 provided officers joined ICS prior to 1921 entitled to annuity of £1000

anchor.surface_text: The 1972 Act has changed Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Reg- ulations. Regulation 561 provided that officers who had joined the Indian Civil Service prior to 1921 were entitled to annuity of pond 1000.

facts.text: Officers joined ICS after 1921 entitled to annuity of Rs. 10,666-10-8 subject to minimum £1000 under Reg 561

anchor.surface_text: Officers who joined the Indian Civil Service after 1921 were entitled to annuity of Rs. 10,666-10-8. The annuity was subject to a minimum of pond 1000.

facts.text: On 15 August 1947, ICS member on retirement entitled to annuity Rs. 10,666-10-8 subject to min £1000 under Reg 561

anchor.surface_text: On 15 August, 1947 under Regulation 561 of the Civil Service Regulations a member of the Indian Civil Service on retirement was entitled to an annuity of Rs. 10,666-10-8 subject to a minimum of pond 1000.

facts.text: Secretary of State despatch dated 25th February 1928 laid down rate of exchange 1 sh-6d to a rupee for pension

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated here that the Secretary of State in a despatch dated 25th February, 1928 laid down the rate of exchange for the purpose of pension and overseas pay etc. at 1 sh-6 d to a rupee,

facts.text: Regulation 561 amended by President under Article 309, came into force on 12 June 1956

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 561 was amended by the President under the provisions of Article 309. The amended came into force on 12 June, 1956.

facts.text: After 1956 amendment, Indian ICS members entitled to annuity Rs. 13,333.33 payable in India in rupees only

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the amendment Indian members of the Indian Civil Service who retired or sought retirement were entitled under Regulation 561, to an annuity of Rs. 13,333.33 payable in India in rupees only.

facts.text: Rs. 13,333.33 equivalent to £1000 converted at 1 sh-6d to rupee

anchor.surface_text: The annuity of Rs. 13,333.33 was equivalent to pond 1000 companyverted into rupees at the rate of 1 sh-6 d to a rupee.

facts.text: Petitioners and appellants in CA 147/71, 2467/72, 2468/72 entitled to Rs. 13,333.33 under Reg 561

anchor.surface_text: Under Regulation 561 the petitioners and the appellants in CA 147 of 1971, 2467 and 2468 of 1972 were entitled to an annuity of, Rs. 13,333.33 subject to reduction for Family Pension

facts.text: 1972 Act came into force on 1 October 1972

anchor.surface_text: The 1972 Act came into force on 1 October, 1972.

facts.text: Under section 7 of 1972 Act, petitioners and appellants entitled to annuity Rs. 13,333.33

anchor.surface_text: Under section 7 of the 1972 Act the petitioners and the appellants are entitled to an annuity of Rs. 13,333.33 subject to reduction of Family Pension and Death-cum- Retirement Gratuity.

facts.text: Petitioners and appellants in CA 147/71, 2467/72, 2468/72 all joined ICS after 1921

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners and the appellant in CA 147 of 1971 and CA 2467 and 2468 of 1972 all joined the Indian Civil Service after 1921.

facts.text: Petitioner Raman contended that salary, annuity and pension of ICS members are basic structure which could not be amended by Parliament

anchor.surface_text: Shri Raman one of the petitioners appearing in person submitted that the salary, annuity and pension of the members of the Indian Civil Service were, to borrow his words, basic structure which companyld number be amended by any Act of Parliament.

facts.text: Petitioners contended entitled to annuity by converting £1000 into Indian currency at official rate of exchange

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Raman in particular and others who supported him companytended that officers who belonged to the Indian Civil Service were entitled to payment of annuity by companyverting pound 1000 into Indian currency at the official rate of exchange.

facts.text: Court held amendment of Reg 561 does not infringe Articles 14 and 16

anchor.surface_text: The amendment of Regulation 561 does number infringe the provisions of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitions fail, CA 268/72 allowed, CA 147/71, 2467/72, 2468/72 dismissed

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, the petitions fail and CA 268 of 1972 is allowed and C.A. 147 of 1971, 2467 and 2468 of 1972 are dismissed.

facts.text: Pension to which ICS members entitled on 15 August 1947 has not been altered

anchor.surface_text: The pension to which these members of the Indian Civil Service were entitled on 15 August, 1947 has number been altered.

facts.text: 1972 Act section 8 provides no former officer entitled to pension in sterling, outside India, or rupee equivalent exceeding Rs.13,333.33 to £1000

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 of the Act provides that numberformer Secretary of State Service officer shall be entitled, or be deed ever to have been entitled, to claim  a  pension in sterling or  b  that his pension shall be paid outside India or  c  where his pension was expressed in sterling or a fixed sterling minimum was applicable in respect of the pension payable to him, that his pension shall be companyputed in the rupee equivalent of the amount fixed in sterling at a rate of exchange exceeding the rate of Rs. 13,333.33 to pond 1000 sterling.

arguments.claim: Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Regulations could be amended by the Former Secretary of State Service Officers Conditions of Service Act, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls for determination in these petitions and appeal is whether Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Regulations could be amended by the Former Secretary of State,

arguments.claim: The amendment of Regulation 561 does not infringe the provisions of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The amendment of Regulation 561 does not infringe the provisions of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution. The amendment makes no distinction in the matter of payment of pension to the members of the Indian Civil Service retiring after 12 June, 1956 irrespective of the fact that they are citizens of India or are of non-Indian domicile if they draw their pension in India.

arguments.claim: Regulation 561 was validly amended by the President under Article 309 in 1956 delinking pension from sterling

anchor.surface_text: Regulation 561 was amended by the President under the provisions of Article 309. The amended came into force on 12 June, 1956. As a result of the amendment Indian members of the Indian Civil Service who retired or sought retirement were entitled under Regulation 561, to an annuity of Rs. 13,333.33 payable in India in rupees only.

arguments.claim: Article 312A introduced by the Constitution (Twenty-eighth Amendment) Act confers power on Parliament to vary or revoke conditions of service as respects pension prospectively or retrospectively

anchor.surface_text: Article 312A which was introduced by the Constitution Twentyeighth Amendment Act confers power on Parliament to make a law to vary or revoke, whether prospectively or retrospectively, the conditions of service as respects pension of persons who, having been appointed by Secretary of State or Secretary of State in Council to a Civil Service of the Crown in India before the commencement of this Constitution,

arguments.claim: The pension to which members of the Indian Civil Service were entitled on 15 August 1947 has not been altered

anchor.surface_text: The pension to which these members of the Indian Civil Service were entitled on 15 August, 1947 has not been altered.

arguments.claim: There is no constitutional vice in fixing the rate of exchange and the mode of payment by legislation

anchor.surface_text: There is no constitutional vice in fixing the rate of exchange and the mode of payment by legislation. The petitioners and the appellants have neither right nor merit in the alleged claims.

arguments.claim: Indian currency is the legal tender and annuitants reside in India

anchor.surface_text: The annuitants reside in India. Indian currency is the legal tender.

arguments.claim: Under the 1972 Act, members are entitled to Rs. 13,333.33 equivalent to £1000 at 1s-6d rate, no change from previous

anchor.surface_text: The members of the former Indian Civil Service and of the Indian Administrative Service are under the 1972 Act entitled to an annuity of Rs. 13,333.33 which is equivalent to pound 1000 converted into rupees at the rate of 1 sh-6 d to a rupee. There has been no change.

holdings.text: Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Regulations could be amended by the Former Secretary of State Service Officers Conditions of Service Act, 1972

anchor.surface_text: The only question which falls for determination in these petitions and appeal is whether Regulations 561 and 983 of the Civil Service Regulations could be amended by the Former Secretary of State,

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1972 Act enacted under Article 312A empowers variation or revocation of pension conditions prospectively or retrospectively; petitions challenging amendment dismissed except CA 268/72 allowed

holdings.text: The amendment of Regulation 561 does not infringe the provisions of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The amendment of Regulation 561 does not infringe the provisions of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution. The amendment makes no distinction in the matter of payment of pension to the members of the Indian Civil Service retiring after 12 June, 1956 irrespective of the fact that they are citizens of India or are of non-Indian domicile if they draw their pension in India.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment treats all members retiring after 12 June 1956 equally regardless of citizenship or domicile when pension drawn in India; payable only in rupees in India

holdings.text: Article 312A confers power on Parliament to make a law to vary or revoke, whether prospectively or retrospectively, the conditions of service as respects pension of former Secretary of State service officers

anchor.surface_text: Article 312A which was introduced by the Constitution Twentyeighth Amendment Act confers power on Parliament to make a law to vary or revoke, whether prospectively or retrospectively, the conditions of service as respects pension of persons who, having been appointed by Secretary of State or Secretary of State in Council to a Civil Service of the Crown in India before the commencement of this Constitution,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of Article 312A introduced by 28th Amendment; basis for validity of 1972 Act

holdings.text: The pension to which these members of the Indian Civil Service were entitled on 15 August, 1947 has not been altered

anchor.surface_text: The pension to which these members of the Indian Civil Service were entitled on 15 August, 1947 has not been altered.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entitlement fixed at Rs. 10,666-10-8 subject to minimum £1000 equivalent; 1956 and 1972 amendments maintain Rs. 13,333.33 equivalent at 1s-6d rate

holdings.text: The salary, annuity and pension of the members of the Indian Civil Service were not basic structure which could not be amended by any Act of Parliament

anchor.surface_text: Shri Raman one of the petitioners appearing in person submitted that the salary, annuity and pension of the members of the Indian Civil Service were, to borrow his words, basic structure which could not be amended by any Act of Parliament. This is only to be stated to be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner claim rejected as absurd and unsupported in law

holdings.text: Officers of the Indian Civil Service were not entitled to payment of annuity by converting pound 1000 into Indian currency at the official rate of exchange

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Raman in particular and others who supported him contended that officers who belonged to the Indian Civil Service were entitled to payment of annuity by converting pound 1000 into Indian currency at the official rate of exchange. The contentions of the petitioners are that it is their basic right to be paid annuity in Indian currency at the official rate of exchange of rupee to a pound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entitlements historically regulated by fixed rate of 1s-6d; alleged rights absurd and unsupportable; no change from 1947 entitlement

holdings.text: There is no constitutional vice in fixing the rate of exchange and the mode of payment by legislation

anchor.surface_text: There is no constitutional vice in fixing the rate of exchange and the mode of payment by legislation. The petitioners and the appellants have neither right nor merit in the alleged claims.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Annuitants reside in India where Indian currency is legal tender; 1972 Act fixes rate at historical 1s-6d equivalent without alteration

holdings.text: The petitions fail and CA 268 of 1972 is allowed and C.A. 147 of 1971, 2467 and 2468 of 1972 are dismissed

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons, the petitions fail and CA 268 of 1972 is allowed and C.A. 147 of 1971, 2467 and 2468 of 1972 are dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Challenges to 1972 Act rejected based on statutory and constitutional validity, no infringement of rights

anchor.surface_text: The amendment of Regulation 561 does not infringe the provisions of Articles 14 and 16 of the Constitution. edges.explanation: Holding denies entitlement to annuity payment by pound conversion at official rate, directly addressing the issue with adjacent character spans and matching descriptions

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner Raman in particular and others who supported him contended that officers who belonged to the Indian Civil Service were entitled to payment of annuity by converting pound 1000 into Indian currency at the official rate of exchange. The contentions of the petitioners are that it is their basic right to be paid annuity in Indian currency at the official rate of exchange of rupee to a pound.
For the foregoing reasons, the petitions fail and CA 268 of 1972 is allowed and C.A. 147 of 1971, 2467 and 2468 of 1972 are dismissed.
